In the case without autocorrelation, each newly infected individual draws its transmission rate independently from a binary probabilistic distribution, that is, choosing λ 1 with probability 1 − π
c , and choosing a larger transmission rate λ 2 with probability π
c . We set π
c = 0.1, corresponding to the proportion of risky subpopulation in [ 9]. We made the comparison for two settings, one with lower level of heterogeneity: λ 1 = 2 and λ 2 = 6 (corresponding to the mean transmission rate μ λ = 2.4 and the heterogeneity CV λ = 0.5); and the other with higher level of heterogeneity: λ 1 = 1 and λ 2 = 15, corresponding to the same μ λ = 2.4 but now CV λ = 1.75.
